pr_title: refactoring: App classpath resources should be access via ResourceProvider

timeline.message:
refactoring: App classpath resources should be access via
ResourceProvider

Fixes #9269
fix: report the exception in the logger

timeline.bodyText: Missing service parameter from the javaDoc
timeline.author: caalador

timeline.bodyText:
Should we just have a method getResourceProvider in service so you wouldn't need to do this dance in every place as now it's basically the same code in every place and then we could have some null checks in place also.
Perhaps even have the shorthand of getApplicationResource in  service
timeline.author: caalador

replies.bodyText:
getApplicaitonResource shouldn't be in the service for sure.
Just because this method may be called when there is no any service yet at all (and this is not the only method in ResourceProvider).
For the same reason I would avoid having getResourceProvider  in the service.
The only reason why getResourceProvider  could have been added into the service is just a shorthand.
But this is not a good reason. The shorthand can be a static method like SomeUtilClass.getResourceProvider(VaadinSevrice). Not sure whether it's worth or not: I don't like static methods.
Overall : it's antipattern vs pattern and I'm not sure whether this is an antipattern or a pattern.
Technically there is no any logical reason to have ResourceProvider in the service (except a convenience method).
And declaring such method in the service litters API: there can be other services which are used in various places in the code like ResourceProvider. Should we add a getter for every such service ? And should we do this every time when such service appears? (the opposite is also true: we may decide to remove any service at any time).
Such (I would say antipattern) allows to dynamically get service in the same way as OSGi allows to do this without modifying API everytime when new service appears (or disappears).
It has advantage (described above: keep API the same) and disadvantage: one has to know that there is a service which can be accessed this way.
For me the advantage at the moment outbalances a bit disadvantages.
replies.author: denis-anisimov

replies.bodyText: Perhaps we could have in ResourceProvider the method as getXYZ(service) the main concern is the moment you get a null on lookup which should be handled nicer than the current NPE that it will throw which in some cases is hard to know what was null for instance if the line is service.getContext().getAttribute(Lookup.class).lookup(ResourceProvider.class)
replies.author: caalador

replies.bodyText:
ResourceProvider is an interface.
It may not have any static method.
service.getContext().getAttribute(Lookup.class)  may not be null
lookup.lookup(ResourceProvider.class) also may not be null.
(at least in runtime)
The code is done in the way that the instances always there because they are set in the servlet init phase.
But I don't really see a benefit having this in a separate method: you may not prevent NPE (NPE means everything is broken, it may just not happen, it's not possible to do a fallback). And if NPE happens (e.g. in the test) then how you may properly handle this ?
It just means that the test is not properly configured and I don't see any good message which may say something meaningful here.
replies.author: denis-anisimov

replies.bodyText:
The only benefit which I see for now is replacing NPE with some ISE or RuntimeException.
And I don't think replacing one exception with another is really a benefit.
May be it's worth to add a check in getAttribute()  method specifically for Lookup.class  parameter and log a warning but this is a separate ticket.
